Put simply, Substrate is Unreal Engine's
new material system, and it
fundamentally changes how we think about
shading. In legacy workflows, you had to
pick a shading model like default lit or
subsurface and hope it fit your use
case. Substrate removes that
restriction. It lets you directly blend
in shading behaviors like fuzz, clear
coat, or subsurface scattering without
switching models or resorting to hacks.
Take the image on this slide. It shows a
complex material topology that would
have been impossible in the old system.
It blends a subsurface base with a
metallic layer which combines with a
tinted clear coat and finally a variable
thickness goo layer is drizzled on top.
It's synthetic, yes, but there is
similar layering in real use cases like
sweat on skin or ice over rock.
For artists, substrate gives much more
expressive control and helps materials
behave more intuitively under lighting,
especially for layered or physically
rich surfaces.
With legacy materials in Unreal, only
one shading model could be active per
pixel. That meant you had to choose. Do
you want subsurface scattering or do you
want clear coat? You couldn't combine
them freely. This limitation made it
difficult to build complex or hybrid
materials, especially when the surface
needed to exhibit multiple shading
behaviors.
Substrate replaces that constraint with
slabs, which are modular, physically
parameterized building blocks that you
define directly in the material graph.
These slabs are self-contained models of
light surface interaction. Essentially,
they're shading models in their own
right, but with the added benefit that
they can be composed using operators
like blending or mixing.
The expressive range of the simplest
substrate materials is broad enough to
recreate many previously custom or
shader hacked effects such as oily skin,
automotive paint, or fabrics with
anisotropic highlights.
In practical terms, substrate allows
developers to blend closures in an odd
hoke fashion. That means far fewer
restrictions on how materials are
layered and a lot more freedom to
express what a surface is rather than
fitting it into a predefined model.

this kind of complex layering behavior
in a later slide, but for now, just keep
in mind that substrate doesn't ask you
to choose a shading model. It allows you
to build one tailored to your material's
actual properties.
At its most fundamental level, substrate
is a complete reconfiguration of the
GBuffer. And we'll get to the asterisk
there in a bit. Instead of using a fixed
GBuffer layout like traditional deferred
rendering, Substrate stores material
properties in packed GPU buffers.
So, this isn't just about changing a
shading model. We're actually replacing
how the renderer stores and evaluates
material data per pixel.
One key consequence of this change is
that hardware blending is no longer
supported. But what we gain is the
ability to store multiple closures per
pixel and to blend material data in ways
that were previously impossible,
enabling far more nuanced and dynamic
shading behavior. Substrate is also
designed for scalability. It can
simplify or drop expensive
configurations automatically on
platforms that don't support the full

consoles or even if the material falls
outside the budget established in the
INI files.
To make this work, Substrate scales
memory allocation dynamically based on
pixel complexity and the threshold for
simplification is configurable per
platform.
What this means for you is you can
author a high-end material once and it
will scale down to your target hardware
without duplicating assets or
fragmenting your content pipeline.

A slab is the fundamental building block

parameterized way.

The slab interface defines how light

It's physically parameterized and built
